title: 110_s851
content: The Act is titled the "Higher Education Opportunity Act of 2007" and includes an amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding the Higher Education Opportunity Credit. The Higher Education Opportunity Act of 2007 includes a provision in the Internal Revenue Code allowing a tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses paid by eligible students. The credit is 100% of expenses up to $1,000 and 50% of expenses between $1,000 and $3,000. The tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses is 100% of expenses up to $1,000, 50% of expenses between $1,000 and $3,000, and 20% of expenses exceeding $3,000 but not exceeding $5,500. The credit amount is reduced based on modified adjusted gross income. The tax credit for qualified tuition and related expenses is reduced based on modified adjusted gross income, with specific thresholds for different income levels. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' is the taxpayer's adjusted gross income for the taxable year, increased by any excluded amounts. The tax credit for tuition expenses is limited based on the total tax liability for the year. The tax credit for tuition expenses is limited based on the total tax liability for the year, with restrictions on the number of eligible students and taxable years. The tax credit for tuition expenses is limited based on the total tax liability for the year, with restrictions on the number of eligible students and taxable years. An election to apply this section to an eligible student cannot be made if such an election is in effect for the student for four prior taxable years. The credit is only allowed for a year if the individual is at least a half-time student for part of the year. The tax credit for tuition expenses is limited based on total tax liability, with restrictions on eligible students and taxable years. The credit is not allowed if a student has been convicted of a felony drug offense involving controlled substances before the end of the academic period. The term 'eligible student' refers to a student who meets specific requirements and is carrying at least half of a full-time workload for their course of study. The term 'qualified tuition and related expenses' includes tuition and fees necessary for enrollment at an eligible educational institution for the taxpayer, spouse, or dependents eligible for a deduction under section 151. The qualified tuition and related expenses at an eligible educational institution include 50 percent of amounts paid for books, not exceeding $250 per taxable year. The qualified tuition and related expenses for an eligible student do not include expenses for sports, games, hobbies, student activity fees, athletic fees, insurance expenses, or other non-academic fees. The term 'eligible educational institution' refers to an institution described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible to participate in a program under title IV of the same Act. Taxpayers can choose not to apply this section to qualified tuition. Special rules apply to the qualified tuition and related expenses for an individual, including the requirement to include the individual's name and taxpayer identification number on the tax return. Adjustments are made for certain scholarships and other financial aid. The qualified tuition and related expenses for an individual are reduced by amounts paid for the individual's benefit, including qualified scholarships, educational assistance allowances, and certain payments. The text discusses payments for educational expenses that are excludable from gross income under US law. If a deduction is allowed for an individual by another taxpayer in the same calendar year, the expenses paid by the dependent are treated differently. If a taxpayer pays qualified tuition and related expenses for an academic period that begins during the calendar year, the expenses are treated differently if another taxpayer claims a deduction for the same individual in that year. For an academic period starting in the first 3 months after the taxable year, it will be considered as part of that taxable year. No double benefit is allowed for expenses eligible for both a credit and a deduction. Married individuals filing separately are not eligible for the credit unless they file a joint return. If the taxpayer and their spouse file a joint return for the taxable year, the section applies only if the taxpayer is a nonresident alien individual treated as a resident alien of the United States. Inflation adjustments affect the dollar limitation on the credit amount for taxable years after 2008. For taxable years after 2008, dollar amounts under subsection (a) will increase based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year, using 2007 as the base year for calculation. "In taxable years after 2008, dollar amounts in subsection (b)(1)(B) will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $100. Income limits will be increased by the cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3)." "In taxable years after 2008, dollar amounts in subsection (b)(1)(B) will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $100. Income limits will be increased by the cost-of-living adjustment determined under section 1(f)(3). The Secretary may prescribe regulations to carry out this section." The section allows for regulations to recapture the credit if refunded in a later taxable year. Additionally, the deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses is repealed. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by making various changes to different sections, including striking the item relating to section 222 and making conforming amendments to sections 26(a), 62(a), 72(t)(7), and 221(d). The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by making changes to different sections, including striking and inserting specific sections in various paragraphs and clauses. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by changing references to specific sections in different clauses and paragraphs. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by changing references to specific sections in different clauses and paragraphs. References to section 25A are updated in various sections of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by updating references to section 25A in subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by this section apply to education expenses paid after December 31, 2007, for academic periods beginning after that date.
